turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments first this morning in Number 1301, Gannett Company against DePasquale.
Mr. Bernius you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Thank Your Honor.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
I represent petitioner Gannett Company, Incorporated which seeks reversal of the judgment of the New York State Court of Appeals.

The question presented by this case is what restrictions to the First and Sixth Amendments placed upon a trial judge, rejects the public and press from a traditionally public suppression hearing in order to prevent press publication concerning that hearing.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you place your argument principally on one amendment as against the other or on both?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, I believe our argument is based first on the First Amendment, secondly on the public trial clause of the Sixth Amendment.
They are two separate grounds --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Which do you prefer?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: I prefer neither Your Honor.
I think they're birth -- both equally important.
I think the damages in the First Amendment aspect are clear as are they in the Sixth Amendment.
The facts in this case are very brief.
Case arises out of the disappearance in mid-July 1976 of a Rochester man while fishing on the Finger Lakes in New York State.

Respondents Greathouse and Jones were subsequently arrested for his murder and in November 1976, a suppression hearing in the case was commenced before Judge DePasquale in Seneca County Court which is located approximately 40 miles from Rochester.
At the beginning of the hearing the defense attorney has requested that the public and press be ejected saying that evidence which might or may not be admitted at trial would be heard at the hearing.
Judge DePasquale with no inquiry or argument and without hearing any evidence whatsoever in -- or making any findings of fact ejected the public, ejected the press.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Incidentally Mr. Bernius, is there a transcript to what happened?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes Your Honor at pages 4 through 6 of the appendix is the transcript of that ejection, a request --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And was there a transcript made of the -- after the ejection of the proceedings following?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: I believe so Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That transcript is not here?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: It is not in the record before this Court Your Honor.
It was released after the defendants pleaded guilty which was subsequent to the time that the special proceeding, prohibition and mandamus was commenced.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did the trial judge at the time of this original order indicate that the transcript would or would not be available when the case was terminated --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, at --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- when the trial was terminated?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: At the initial ejection, there was no colloquy at all concerning the availability of a transcript in the future.
During the hearing, the reporter, the Rochester newspaper reporter who had been excluded asked for postponement in order that attorneys might appear and argue that.
The postponement was denied and the hearing finished in secret on Friday afternoon.
On Monday morning, attorneys appeared for Gannett sought vacator of the order of closure and at that point since the hearing was over, we asked for access to the transcript.
Judge DePasquale heard argument on our motion but denied vacator of the order and also denied access to the transcript in perpetuity.
After the plea of guilty, he had a change of heart and released the transcript to the public which was --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Has it been lodged with us Mr. Bernius?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: No, it has not Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The entire record has not been lodged here?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, the entire record is in the appendix.
Transcript of the suppression hearing was not part of the record in the Appellate Division or in the Court of Appeals.This is a separate proceeding distinct from the criminal proceeding.
It was a special proceeding.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So your answer is no, the entire record isn't here, is that right?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: The record of the criminal case is not before this Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The record of the trial.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Of the -- well --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: The suppression hearing is not -- the transcript is not before the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But when he entered a plea, a trial at some stage began in trying to separate the pretrial from what he decided to do finally was to plead guilty, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, there was no trial.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Pretrial covers all of the things you've been telling us about on the exclusion of the public.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When you --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When you said that this was a separate proceeding, you mean that Gannett's proceeding to obtain release of or access to the suppression motion was in -- under New York law separate proceeding from the criminal proceeding.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.
What happened were essentially two things.
We were notified about the situation immediately or shortly before the suppression hearing in the criminal case ended.
That was on a Friday afternoon and this is an outlying county.
On Monday morning, I essentially appeared as an interested party or as an amicus in the criminal case.
I went back to Judge DePasquale to ask him if he would change his mind.
He did not and he denied our motion.
The next day, we started a separate distinct civil proceeding of prohibition and mandamus in the Appellate Division.
So this is an appeal from --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the case we have is Gannett, it has -- the title of this case is Gannett?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's right Your Honor, its Gannett against the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So it has nothing to do with a criminal case.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: It's a civil case.
It's in the nature of prohibition and mandamus challenging the orders in a criminal case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What did you make part of the record on that application?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your -- the -- we -- this case started Your Honor with the petition which is -- appears at page 21 -- page 19 of the appendix.
And the petition challenges the orders in the criminal case which were issued by Judge DePasquale.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And attached to it as exhibits or whether --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, yes.
The orders and the transcripts of the criminal --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's what --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: -- proceeding are -- were attached as exhibits --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Or attached as --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: -- in the writ of prohibition.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Incidentally, I take it this was a stenographic transcript not a tape recording.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's right Your Honor.
It was a stenographer --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The proceedings are (Inaudible) 13 on your case.
That's all we have on the proceedings, right?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, what has happened with this appendix Your Honor is that things have been put in a chronological order.
The transcripts of the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I mean, is there other -- any thing or -- of what happened at the motion other than what is on the 13?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: No.
At the time we started this that was still secret and it was sealed.
When Gannett commenced the separate civil proceeding and mandamus in the Appellate Division, next to that -- those papers were the newspaper articles which had appeared prior to the closure.
Now those articles are irrelevant to justify the closure because they were not before Judge DePasquale.
He did not consider them and indeed, no reference was ever made by any of the respondents to those articles.
But I would submit that those articles are directly relevant to the issue before this Court because they demonstrate and put in a factual context to the opinion of the Court of Appeals.
The articles appeared over a course of approximately two and a half weeks from the time of the disappearance of this man until the time the defendants were arraigned on the murder indictment.
They appeared on seven days out of that 18-day period and they appeared contemporaneously with the major events in the criminal investigation.
There are articles in the morning and evening paper when this man disappeared.
There were --and then there were articles when the defendants were arrested, when they were indicted, arraigned and so on.
The last articles appeared at the time of the defendants' arraignment which was 91 days before the commencement of the suppression hearing.
There was no further publicity in that interim period.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Suppose in a criminal trial Mr. Bernius, the -- either the prosecution or the defense wants to take a deposition of an absent witness either out of the United States or situated in someway where attendance, personal attendance can't be compelled.
Would you think the Sixth Amendment and your other arguments would require that the taking of the testimony of that witness be a public open hearing?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: If -- a criminal trial Your Honor, yes I do and I think --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, not a criminal trial, very carefully he stood before trial -- pretrial.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: In a criminal proceeding, yes it would Your Honor.
I believe that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if it's never offered in evidence?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, that is I think irrelevant at the time of the proceeding, that that deposition has all the characteristics of a criminal trial.
I would assume that a witness is going to testify.
The parties are present.
There is an oath.
There is cross-examination.
The defendant has a right to be present.
All the characteristics of the criminal trial itself, the post jury criminal trial.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: s it not common that in pretrial depositions both in civil and criminal cases that particularly if no judge is present and that's usually the case that there are many question which you're asked and answered with the reserved right to challenge their admissibility at the -- when asked and if the deposition is offered, is that not so?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes.
Yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How was it part of the trial until it's offered in evidence?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well it -- Your Honor, it is an important stage in the process and there is a development, an adversary proceeding to develop a factual record upon which a subsequent determination will be made.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, will the subsequent determination be made if it's never offered?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, what --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: It -- if (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What will there be for the Court to rule on?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, it won't be made based on that but there is no guarantee and I think it's -- the analogy to a suppression hearing is clear that at the time of the suppression hearing there's no guarantee at all or no -- that the evidence will in fact be admitted a trial.

In fact, there is no guarantee that there will be a trial but nevertheless that is -- could well be the critical stage in the process but if the testimony of the suppression hearing transcript is not to be offered or the evidence that is given in the hearing is not to be offered at trial, the reason for that is because a judge makes a determination that that evidence is not admissible.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is that the only circumstance?
What if for the party who has called for the deposition just decides that isn't needed and therefore he doesn't offer it?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, I think that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Suppose that the prosecution takes this pretrial testimony in an abundance of caution and when they put their case in they find they approved -- established the same facts by other witnesses and they never bothered to put the deposition in evidence.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is it part of the trial then?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Not in a strict sense but in a generic sense, yes Your Honor.

I don't think that the fact that a jury is selected is a mystical concept that precludes the public's right to attend and to observe and be aware of the entire gamut of the proceedings where there is testimony, where there is cross-examination, where there is an attempt to establish either the prosecution's point or the defense point.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, does the Sixth Amendment speak in terms of proceedings or does it speak in terms of trial?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well Your Honor, it speaks in terms obviously of a trial but it's our position that a suppression hearing is clearly for the constitutional purpose as part of the trial.
In fact, the statistics are that 90% of all criminal cases and 100% of criminal cases in Seneca County for two and a half years were completed at the pretrial stage.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what -- whoa! Counsel, what if the statistic show that 90% of the complaints of the prosecuting attorney were never even prosecuted by information or indictment by him, would that make the prosecuting attorney's conference among his colleagues part of the trial because that was the way so many cases were disposed of?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well Your Honor, I'd -- there is a distinction obviously between that situation and the situation where there is a formal proceeding and adversary proceeding, witnesses are sworn and a judge is going to make a determination based on that testimony, a determination of fact.
I think that really the answer to the question of when does a trial commence is to be found in the purposes that are served by the public trial clause.
One of those purposes obviously is to protect the defendant and see that his interests are not abused by the prosecuting authorities but it goes beyond that.
There are interests in the public, specifically third parties may have a direct interest in the case but the interest of the public in seeing that the --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why then that the framers cast the language of the Sixth Amendment in saying the accused shall enjoy the right of a public trial.
Why didn't they say the press shall have access to the trial?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that based on the prior history and which is developed at -- to a certain extent in our brief but in the -- at the amicus brief for the National Association of Broadcasters more extensively, there was really no indication that a common law, the right of a public trial accrued to the defendant at all.

There were broader purposes behind it but the codification was in the constitution I think recognizes that the defendant should specifically be guaranteed a fair trial, a public trial but the part -- inherent in that clause, the public trial clause is a recognition I would submit that the public has an equal interest.
I think that the purposes that are served by the clause mean that it should not be read literally.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well the framers shouldn't have taken an odd way of expressing it if they meant to adopt your view.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't think so because it is again inherent in that phrase, public trial is a notion, a concept that the public has an interest in it and based on the prior history of common law and based on the purpose it served by the public trial clause --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, how can you tell what the purposes served are except by reading the clause?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: I think Your Honor by looking at the history and really analyzing it in the terms of the essential nature of the guarantee and what it does.

The overwhelming purpose served is as far as I can tell, the insurance of the confidence of the public, I mean in the judicial system, in the criminal justice system, the public nature of trials is in effect necessary to the vitality of that system and its viability.
I don't think that our criminal justice system would long last if proceedings of this nature were held in secret and I think that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Bernius, you argue anyway don't you that independently of the Sixth Amendment public trial that the press at least has the First Amendment right to be present.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Absolutely Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, before you get in to that, I know you're going to argue that, I hope, but what if -- does the public also have a First Amendment right?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: I think so Your Honor, yes.
I do -- we do not --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You don't claim any more --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- for the press than for the public?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Absolutely not.
We think that the public right is equivalent to the press right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And this is First Amendment and not the Sixth Amendment.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's right.
The -- their --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: When you get to that, did you have any cases from this Court that under the First Amendment guarantees access to information.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor the -- I believe I have an analogous case history.
First, there was no -- there's no question in this case that the public and the press had a right to be present prior to the motion to exclude them.
The Court of Appeals indicated that in its opinion, the respondents concede that.

It's -- the right to be present I think derives primarily from the right to gather information which was recognized by this Court in Branzburg and I know that the right to gather information is not without limits but I would submit that if there is any sort of right to gather information, it must exist at trials, it must exist in the streets and other public forums and I think that for the purposes of the right to gather information, the public forum test which was developed in most specifically articulated in the Grayned case gives very pertinent guidance.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you take that so far as to have the right to be present at a conference of members of an appellate court.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: No Your Honor because --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: -- the presence of the public or the press that the conferences of this Court or any other Court would be basically incompatible with the primary function of the -- of that -- of the public institution at that time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Except I thought you based your approach a little while ago on the right to gather information.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's right but it's not unli -- it's clearly not unlimited Your Honor and I think that the Court has answered that in some of the present cases that's answered that to a certain extent in the public forum cases, Marsh against Alabama, Adderly against Florida that was -- the cases where there is an asserted right to be present to exercise First Amendment freedoms.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Bernius, what is the primary function of the suppression hearing?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: The primary function of the suppression hearing is to determine Your Honor whether a jury should hear specific evidence whether it is sufficiently reliable.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And if the Court determines that it should not be heard and if the press has heard that evidence, is there any restriction on the press publishing it so it will come to the attention of the jury?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: The -- no, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So how could the primary function of the suppression hearing be performed if you're correct?Well, Your Honor there is -- that is really I believe the -- one of the principle faults in the Court of Appeals' opinion, the assumption that publication by definition means a -- that the jury will be affected by this information.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: The orders in this case were aimed directly at publication.
They're aimed at keeping the public ignorant of the facts of this hearing.
And their -- that the basis of the orders is public ignorance with the hope that somehow an indirect benefit will filter back to the trial.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if the judge modified this order and expressly said that at the determination of the trial, the transcript of the suppression hearing will be made available to anyone who wants it?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then is there any suppression of information?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes there is Your Honor.
I think that this Court in Nebraska Press very much dealt at length with the problems in delaying publication of news concerning the criminal justice system.
Secondly, the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But there you were dealing with the trial, not pretrial, weren't you?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Nebraska Press --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Nebraska didn't --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: -- was a pretrial situation Your Honor.
The delay in this case is just as serious.

Secondly, its -- if the order in this case is in a sense more dramatic than in Nebraska Press because not only is there a delay but there is an absolute denial of the public's knowledge of what went on in the suppression hearing.

As an appellate court, this Court is well aware of the inadequacies of a transcript but the tones, inflections, gestures, everything that makes a presence of a -- of the trier of facts so necessary into a determination, none of those things can be recaptured in the transcript.
And finally --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But if you -- but if (Inaudible) as Mr. Justice Stevens suggested, if the interest of justice and fairness require that the jury not here change of the evidence, how is that purpose served?
I'm not sure you quite fully answered and how is that purpose served if the jury hears it indirectly?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, we make no argument at all that suppression hearings must be open under all circumstances.

We simply say that the damage done to both First Amendment interest and to the public trial interest of the public are serious and that if closure is to take place, it should take place only as the last resort.

What has happened in this case is that the Court of Appeals has said that closure secret proceedings are preferable to change of venue to continuance to an extended voir dire, all those separate alternatives that this Court has on -- repeatedly said and would have been effective to mitigate the effects of pretrial publicity.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If you were in a federal court, you would have some difficulty using change of venue as an alternative if the defendant objected, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, I -- that is -- it's clear that when if there is a continuance or a change of venue or of voir dire, to some extent it's going to inconvenience a defendant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What about the vicinage requirement?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: The vicinage requirement Your Honor deals with the source of a jury.

It doesn't really deal with the venue of the case and I think that the history of the vicinage clause indicates that in -- at the time of the enactment of the Sixth Amendment, there were -- the districts, the federal judicial districts were the equivalent of the states with the exception of Massachusetts and Virginia which had two districts.
So I don't think that the vicinage clause is of any pertinence here since it's number one outdated and number two, it requires a jury from -- essentially from the state and --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, do you think the Government could have said in -- if this case had been pending in federal court, don't worry about supra -- the opening the suppression hearing to the Court because we're going to move for a change of venue down to Tennessee.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well Your Honor, I think that at that point, the defendants would have to make a choice and the fact that a venue may be laid in a certain specific area, the fact that continuance would somehow interfere with a speedy trial.

Those are considerations that all must be weighed but I don't think that in this situation where there are important First Amendment rights and press and public rights that one -- anyone guarantee can be deemed to be absolute.
What we're seeking here is an accommodation of all these potentially conflicting values.
What -- there is Your Honor, no conflict in this case.
There was no showing that publication would -- in any sense have prejudice of the defendant's right to a fair trial.
And there's also been no showing in this case that ejection or closure of this hearing would have help to mitigate that prejudice.
In fact, I think --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course Mr. Bernius, both defense lawyers move for the closure on the very ground that they thought they'd be prejudiced.
Wasn't that the ground the reason it was closed?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: They moved on the basis that evidence which may or may not be admissible at trial was to be admitted in a suppression hearing and ask for it to be closed.
I don't really know what that is.
I have -- we assume that they were concerned with the effects of pretrial publicity but the concern is not enough Your Honor.
There must be some sort of showing to justify this unusual and we submit unconstitutional procedure.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What sort of showing would they make in open court without revealing the very thing they wanted to conceal?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well Your Honor, first, the most dramatic example always is a suppression of a confession.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: In many cases, that the confession is not admitted at a suppression hearing.
It's not really the issue at a suppression --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That the fact that a confession had been made would have to be disclosed, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And would not that be prejudicial to the defendant if it were published in the press and did you not assert the right to publish whatever you heard at the hearing.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: We assert the right to publish whatever we heard but we already knew that there was a confession Your Honor and we could have published that no matter what happened at the hearing.
We could have said and with full --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, maybe in this case but in the normal -- in every case, it isn't true that the press would know whether there was a confession in advance, would it?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, the press would know Your Honor that there was an illegal search and seizure of evidence that there was -- or there was a confession or there was an illegal wiretap.
They would know generically what was going on at that hearing and it seems to me Your Honor and I -- and that the fact that a hearing was closed would not diminish the prejudicial impact of a case.
It in fact would exaggerate it that the public will assume the worst at a close hearing.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You really think that you're a better judge of what's good for the defendants' trial posture than their own counsel.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: No I'm not Your Honor but I think that the defendants' rights are not absolutely paramount if they're not -- if there's not a demonstration that they are in fact prejudiced.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Did you say, (Inaudible) knew here what it was that the defense wanted to suppress?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: We knew that it was a confession Your Honor and we knew that there were --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Anything else?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That we knew that there was a gun that had been seized.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I know but do we know that the motion to suppress identified the -- either it's must have I suppose that were sought to be suppressed.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Not specifically.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: We don't know -- there's nothing in this record to tell us?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What I'm getting at is didn't you -- I know that the gun was found in Michigan, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And hadn't the papers already published that before the suppression hearing?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes Your Honor in July.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you -- you knew that there was a confession which you had not -- had not printed that?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Absolutely, there was in fact the day after the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely it was or was not (Voice Overlap)?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: It was -- I -- there was no reference in any of those articles to a confession and that's an important point Your Honor that the press in this case was responsible even in the article the day after the hearing was closed, the reporter did not refer to the -- to his confessions or guns.
She said -- she described it as evidence which might have been deemed admissible at trial.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if you would have a hearing, I gather one of your protests here is that you should've had a hearing before the order of closure issued, --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- is that right?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And if you had, what would you have argued?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: I would've argued that there was no basis for the closure Your Honor that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, on the ground that whatever was the subject to the motion to suppress had already been published?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's one aspect to it that that closure would be ineffective because we could -- it's not a gag order on the press, they could publish the singly most prejudicial statement that could be made is that the defendants confessed and we could have published that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You said earlier Mr. Bernius in response to Justice Stevens that the defendants' right was not paramount.
I think those were your words.
You mean it's -- the defendants' right to a fair trial is not paramount?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: What I meant to say Your Honor is that there must be an accommodation if a situation arose where the defendants' right to a fair trial was on the line against the public's right, First Amendment and Sixth Amendment rights.
We do not say that the defendants' right should be and should not be paramount.
But it's important to require the New York State Court of Appeals and trial courts throughout the country not to abrogate the rights of the press and public unless it's absolutely necessary.

And that a threat, an actual threat, danger to a fair trial is shown and that -- and there's a showing made that the ejection or closure would be effective and finally and most importantly, there is a showing made that a traditional Sheppard alternatives would be ineffective to cure that danger.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well Mr. Bernius, suppose in this case there had been a hearing and it had -- the issue was a confession and the judge says, I've read the confession and if the newspapers and the media really do their job in getting the word out which they apparently want to do and there's going to be a lot of people hear about this.
And it's going to make it very difficult to get a jury and he makes a finding that there is a serious danger to the fair trial rights of the defendant.
I suppose you take that up on appeal, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, we would obviously have the option of commencing a special proceeding just as we did in this case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I know but you wouldn't lie still for that, I take it.
I just -- I would just like to know what kind of findings in -- by the trial judge would -- that you would accept?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Your Honor, it's the -- I would submit that the appropriate findings that have to be made are the findings in the -- are articulated in Nebraska Press and the fact that --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well suppose he makes them all?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Certainly, there's a -- always the possibility that it could be challenged in a separate proceeding under the law of New York State Your Honor but I doubt very much certainly in this --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what kind of evidence and what kind of danger would you think would have to be present -- that wouldn't be present when there is a flat out confession of the crime by the defendant and the interested media.
I take it you think its -- that in this case at least it was news.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And you were going to -- and you were interested in publishing the result -- the -- what went on at the suppression hearing?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's absolutely Your Honor but (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So you're innocent in publishing the confession if there was one?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Not necessarily.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why didn't -- necessarily, were you going to suppress it or weren't you?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That would be an editorial judgment Your Honor and I think that the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you wanted the right to publish it anyway?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: We want the right to make that decision.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.
You want the right to publish.
And so what kind of evidence would be sufficient to -- on the judges' conclusion that there is a real danger to the --

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: A finding that and a basis for a finding that change a venue to an adjoining county would not have cured the prejudice.
Here, we had a circulation of 1500 newspapers and a population of 36,000 in Seneca County.
The adjoining counties have 350,000 people and judicial district at almost 4 million --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: We aren't just talking about the newspapers, aren't we?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: We're talking about the public and --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, we're talking about the media and we're talking about television.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so it doesn't do you any good to talk about 1500 newspapers.

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Well, that's what (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: We have to talk about television -- the reach of television coverage, don't you?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Certainly and that's not relevant in this case because there's no evidence that there was any television or radio coverage.
And in general, I -- it is --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you don't suppose there wouldn't be, would you if there was an open suppression hearing?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: There's nothing to indicate that there was Your Honor or would have been.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Do you think they're just going to stay home?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: In this case, in -- yes.
But in -- obviously the -- in -- as in Rideau, television coverage is certainly relevant and should be considered.
But in this case, it wasn't considered and the effect of a continuance of voir dire should be evaluated.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Bernius may I ask you.

Whether with or without a prior hearing there had been no closure order and you had sat -- and members of the public however many of them were through the suppression hearing and at the close of it, the judge had then issued an order that you not publish until at least after a jury had been chosen and sequestered.
Anything that you heard that day and similarly address such an order to the general public whoever they are present at the time, you'd still be here, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: On what ground then?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: Under the Nebraska Press test Your Honor.
But the fact that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the -- Judge DePasquale apparently anticipated your answer to Mr. Justice Brennan, didn't he?

turn.speaker: robert_c_bernius
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Bernius
turn.text: The colloquy among lawyers who are involved in this Your Honor is that this is -- this situation is a direct result of the Nebraska press decision and it's our feeling that the mechanism even though the mechanism is ejection rather than injunction, the damages are at least as great and the standards in Nebraska Press should be complied with.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Kobroff.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
The right to a public trial is neither an absolute right of the public nor of the press.

Pretrial hearings and portions of trials had been closed to the public including the media for such situations as preventing disclosure of skyjack profile testimony insuring the emotional and physical health of the pregnant witness protecting the identity of an undercover agent permitting a prosecutrix to testify uninhibitedly at a trial.

Respondent submit that the need to preserve an accused constitutional right to an impartial jury in the County of venue is as important as any of these other interest which have been held to justify closure of criminal proceedings.

Respondents call Edwin Greathouse and David Ray Jones challenged the admissibility of confessions that they had given to Michigan police and physical fruits that these confessions had led the police to seize.
Respondent Judge DePasquale was required to resolve that this evidence had not been obtained in violation of the accused constitutional rights.

The admission of this evidence, this full confessions to the alleged murder and robbery were undoubtedly had been prejudicial to these defendants at their trial and widespread dissemination of these confessions prior to trial could nonetheless have predetermined their guilt in Seneca County.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You wouldn't -- you -- it would just be a timesaver is it -- or would it be anything other than saving your time if there was a hearing about why it was important to close the proceedings and why some other mechanisms wouldn't suffice?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, the New York Court of Appeals has held that the press is certainly entitled to have their views known before the Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that isn't what the trial judge did, is it?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, the situation that was presented to Judge DePasquale was that this motion was made.
There were at least three reporters representing three different newspapers in the courtroom.
None of them mentioned any objections to it.
The District Attorney agreed in effect with the defendants and their motion --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but they made motions later.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, they did in fact make motions later and Judge DePasquale did in fact hold the hearing and listened to their arguments, so they did have the hearing.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did he make -- what kind of determinations did he make?
He just --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- denied the motions, didn't he?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: No, no.

I mean Judge DePasquale heard this argument, heard both sides and then determined that there will be a reasonable probability of prejudice to these defendants had the media gotten access to these confessions and disseminated them.
This --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: This was his finding.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And did he indicate that some other mechanisms wouldn't be sufficient?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, the only reference to that is one of the defense lawyers in the transcript mentions change of venue that is the only alternative specifically mentioned in the appendix --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What does the Court of Appeals think should happen in a normal case?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did they think something should happen in addition to what happened in the trial court?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, they obviously mentioned the alternatives mentioned by this Court in Sheppard, in the opinion.

What you've got here though which make it different I think then what these alternatives, the Sheppard alternatives will do -- is here, the actual the actual poison had not been put out into the community.
We're not in a situation where we're mitigating damage that's already being done, that's already out.
We've got a situation where the damage isn't yet been done.
The -- it isn't widespread and we have an opportunity to stop it at its inception.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the gun is already out?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: The gun and that's true and for that, we might well -- this isn't the only alternative available to a Court to deal with prejudicial publicity.
I mean we have in fact the Sheppard measures that they might also have to be used.
I'm (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but the money -- must the exclusion however be the last alternative or --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, the difficulty with exclusion is the last alternative is that if you wait till the voir dire or if you wait till change of venue can be done, the hearing is already over.
It's too late.
Exclusion is a prophylactic and in a certain situation, unusual situation and there's no denying, this is an unusual case.
It is effective and it should be available to a trial court.

It is a fundamental tenant of due process that the conclusions to be reached in a case will be induced only by evidence and argument in open court and not by any outside influence whether of private talk or public print.
Judge DePasquale had the obligation to prevent suppressed evidence from determining the guilt of Greathouse and Jones and certainly from determining their guilt prior to trial.

To prevent the jury from learning of a coerced confession during trial yet all along needlessly making it available to them to read or hear of it before trial, knocks the claim that our system of law has always endeavored to prevent even the probability of unfairness.
For Judge DePasquale to have allowed public disclosure of potentially tainted evidence which he had the constitutional duty to exclude would involve the Court itself in this taint and illegality.
Respondent Greathouse and Jones were out of state transience, they're accused to the murder and robbery of a local area resident Wayne Clapp, a former police officer with roots in the community.
They have fled -- the respondent and Jones had fled Seneca County sooner after Clapp's disappearance and they were arrested in Michigan several days later.
There they allegedly gave these confessions which were the object to this motion.
If they had prevailed at this hearing, they had a triable defense.
The People's case was entirely circumstantial.
Three men leave on a boat to return.
Gunshots are heard, anchors are missing but there is no body, there is no decease, no corpse and no eyewitnesses to any crime.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Was the body ever found?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Never, never found.
However, if they're unsuccessful at the suppression motion, the defense is almost hopeless.
The full confessions to the crime plus the murder weapon itself is in evidence.
This case had already generated extensive media publicity throughout Seneca County.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But when you make that statement, are you basing it on what's in the appendix?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I think we can accept that.
I think you can also --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: This is far different than in some of the other cases that had been decided here, isn't that -- it doesn't strike you as rather routine reporting, factual reporting?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Oh, Your Honor, I -- they might -- they claim it to be factual reports but as a defense attorney trying this case I mean you would not want to accept that as factual reports.
These are untested, unreliable rumors.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well then, comparing that with the material in Murphy against Florida for instance?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Alright.
The thing with Murphy is when there was no confession that was confronting that or would possibly have been testified and it report in the press.
I think that's a major distinction from what we had in Murphy.
On the day of the suppression motion, we had three reporters in the courtroom that we know of.
Petitioner's reporter, a reporter from the Geneva Times and a reporter from the Syracuse Post.
Together, these papers accounted from us the 85% of the daily newspaper circulation in Seneca County.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is Geneva this county (Inaudible) of Seneca County?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: No, no.
None of these papers are published in Seneca County.

The only newspaper actually published in Seneca County is a weekly newspaper.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where was this Court sitting In Seneca?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Seneca County -- oh, it is --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist

There could be no doubt that this petitioner --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, are these statistics very important?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: No, no.

I think that three newspapers, well, not with three reporters in Seneca County courthouse unless they feel there's a new story and unless they're going to use it.
That's the only reason and the fact that they do have the circulation in that county.
Greathouse and Jones moved for the exclusion of these media representatives.
They argued that the deleterious effects of disclosures of the evidence they sought to suppress, sought to be suppressed would outweigh their right to a public trial.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Kobroff, can you identify what it was they wanted suppressed?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, yes, I mean I know what it was because I've seen the transcript.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But that is not in the record before us though.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, they made a motion to suppress physical evidence.
The motions of statements made to Michigan police and the fruits that these confessions had lived in (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, had there been any publication of what it was that the physical evidence was found in Michigan?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Right.
The -- it is clear that this -- the gun was found with Greathouse -- led the police to, that was reported and was reported that the defendants have moved.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you say the motion is suppressed also, was addressed to statements made to Michigan police?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Oh yes, they had given statements and written confessions --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And there'd been no publication that they had made such statements?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The publication dealt with the fact that New York police were -- they listed -- they gave one statement that Greathouse had made to the Michigan police when he was captured that was he was afraid he'd be shot --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I mean, to the extent that though this already had been published, why --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, the substance of the confessions has not been published.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So is this down merely to the substance of the confessions?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, no.
I mean the actual word itself confession hadn't been used, they used inadmissible statements.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I understood your friend to say that even though the newspaper reporter knew of it they had not published but it's just a matter of their own editorial judgment.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: It would appear so.
But nevertheless the accused did not necessarily feel they had to run the risk that when they see two reporters in the courtroom that this might continue it.
Up to now, they had not gotten the substance of the confessions.
They knew that -- you know, it had been reported that police who were in Michigan interviewing these suspects to learn the apparent motive for the slain.

So they knew that they had gotten something from their interviews but they didn't know what and now, on the day of the suppression hearing, they are going to find out what the “motive” for the apparent slain was.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But they also had published that he was on probation from San Antonio.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Right, I would say that's not exactly a fact.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That the state police hoping to bring the pickup truck back and they're still looking for the 357 magnum revolver which was later found.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes, I think he --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That everything in there but the confession.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: They had a lot of damaging evidence in there.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what did they have other than the confession they didn't have that they published here.
And I'm not -- but I'm just halfway through them.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Right.
It's the confession.
That would be it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's the only thing then, isn't it?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, I think in this case, that's the difference perhaps between having a triable defense and --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well Mr. Kobroff, would you be defending this closure if everything that was a subject to the motion to suppress was already been published?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes, I think that they could still make their emotion.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What justification would there been for the closure of everything that was --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- subject to the motion to suppress and then (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I think that the defense counsel would certainly make the motion.
I mean whether the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I'm not talking about the defense counsel.
I'm asking what justification would there been for the order of closure in that circumstance?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: The same that it would threaten their right to get an impartial jury in that County.
The -- simply because the press has this information simply because the press can publish it doesn't mean that the defendant is therefore is stopped from trying this, you know --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I don't suggest he is.
He can make the motion.
I'm just asking why the judge would enter an order of closure --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- of everything or a subject to motion or --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: That he might well not --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- even of public knowledge.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: He might well not.
I mean he could well take this into consideration and say, "Well, given this situation I don't find a threat and I won't do it".
On the other hand he might well say, "Well yes, I'm going to do this and I'm going to -- then continue the case and you've waive your right to speak".
He might -- they might play the whole instances of things he could do even though the information is out.
I assume in saying that it shouldn't foreclose the defendant or the judge from having this power to -- these means of protecting the defendant's rights simply --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Counsel, in our position, is it solely the protection of the defendants' rights that is involved here, supposing the New York legislature passed the law saying that all trials, all criminal trials in the state shall be closed unless otherwise required by the constitution of the United State and both the defendant and the prosecutor agreed in this particular case that the trial should be closed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist

turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff

The public --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: -- has the right to know.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I think that's a -- I think that you have -- that's a little different I think than perhaps a public trial --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: -- by definition a public trial.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but why do you say by definition of public trial if the New York State legislature says, it's not going to be a public trial?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, no, I just meant that it -- in comparison to an executive closure of a cabinet meeting as compared to that difference.
I think that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yeah but if you're in trial, you're referring to the Sixth Amendment I take it.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but are you -- your argument is that it's the defendant's right?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes it is.

I would also say though that its also the public policy of the State of New York and of every other state that there are other societal interest that are advanced by the right of public trial independent of an accused right to a public trial.
I think it -- there are two sources.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I was trying to find the Jelke case in the New York Court of Appeals.
Do you remember if that's cited in the briefs?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes, I believe I've cited it in my brief.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You do, are you?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.text: Did the judge in this case --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) the citation features.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: It's 308 New York 56, 123 Northeast 2nd 769.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: 308 New York 56.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: 123 Northeast 2nd 769.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did the judge put any limitation on the prosecutor or others releasing statements about the confession or (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff

turn.text: No.
Your Honor, the prosecutor didn't.
He (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does this record show how the media found out about the adjustments of the gun?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I believe it was certain of the statements.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The motions made in open court which was -- were there references to the pistol in the motions in open court?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: No, I believe -- the papers were filed that would've have referred to the physical evidence.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Those were filed though.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But those are public records and they weren't sealed.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: No, they were not sealed.
I believe to answer your question.
I think that most of the source of the news seemed to be the state police, a David (Inaudible) was referred to in various of the articles as giving various quotes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think the threat to the fair trial rights of the defendant are as great from admissible evidence being published ahead of time as inadmissible or not?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: No.
The situation isn't the same.
I mean if the evidence is admissible, there's no reason to insolate the jury from it.
They're going to hear about it anyway.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but suppose you know in voir dire you asked the jury have your read about this case?
They say, "Yeah, we've read all about it".
What do you as a defense counsel do say in it --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I ask a few more questions --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- shrug your shoulders or not?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: No, no.
I asked a few more questions to see exactly what they've read and where they've read it and how it might have affected them.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, suppose one of them says, "I read a verbatim transcript published in the paper of the suppression hearing which turned out that -- and the evidence was admissible"?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
