turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But its not -- it was not sent here?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, it wasn't part of -- this is a collateral proceeding --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes I know.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: -- to the case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Collateral but perhaps of some interest.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes.
But no, it was not sent here.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Could it be?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I suppose so.
I'd tell you what I do have with me if Your Honors would want it is a copy of Judge DePasquale's decision on the hearing that much I have with me if Your Honors would want.
I don't know how permissive this is.
Judge DePasquale could not close this as to the obvious, needles prejudice the accused constitutional right that was about to occur.
He had the duty to protect the respondents Greathouse and Jones' right to a trial by an impartial jury in the County of venue and he did what any prudent judge would have done.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How about the -- do you see any constitutional problems had -- what Judge DePasquale did say, "Well, the press may stay and public may stay".
And they heard the whole thing and at the close of it, he said, "Well, this maybe prejudicial".
And he issues an order directed to the press and public present.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I don't think he could do that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You don't think he --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I think Nebraska Press pretty well decided that issue.
That's just not available.
I mean -- and in addition, I think this course -- this Court had even held in Nebraska Press that what occurs at a public hearing --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: -- cannot be prior -- cannot be a subject to a prior restraint.
So that option was never even available to him as far as that goes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would that fall within what I think Mr. Justice Frankfurter said once the cat is out of the bag, it's impossible to get it back in again.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: That seems to be the rule.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What was the judge's decision in this case on admissibility?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Certain confessions, certain statements were suppressed, the others were not.
Apparently, certain statements were made and then he requested the attorneys then more statements were made and so on.

What is involved in this case is the constitutional right of an accused to a trial by an impartial jury in the County of venue and the right of the public including potential jurors and media representatives have immediate access to pretrial evidentiary suppression hearings.
The case does not concern the right of the press to publish free from prior restraints.
There were no restraints on press publication in this case.
No injunctions restraining the press from publishing anything it wanted to.
No contempt citations punishing the press for having published anything.
Petitioner's error is in equating a temporary denial of public access to potentially inadmissible evidence where the Court ordered direct restraint on publication.
The press was at all time free to publish anything it wanted to about the case at People v.Greathouse and Jones.
Yet the press had learned that what transpired at this in camera proceeding, their publication of this evidence would've been unrestrained.

Petitioner nonetheless argues that the public including prospective jurors' right to immediate access to this testimony, testimony untested by constitutional standards as to reliability, admissibility, testimony found to be probably destructive of an accused constitutional right to an impartial jury that this right to immediate access is entitled with the same constitutional protection as the press' right to publish free from governmental censorship.
Respondent submit that there is no basis in law or reason for this equation.
This has never been the requirement.

This has never been the standard of -- to deny used in instances where courtrooms had been closed and none of the instances to protect the identity of an undercover agent to allow witness to testify uninhibitedly.
This has never been the standard used.
And such a standard would severely undermine an accused constitutional right to an impartial jury.
And without an impartial jury, any other right granted to an accused is meaningless.
An important value in our society, a value embodied in the constitution is of the trial by an impartial jury in the county where the crime was allegedly committed.
This requirement of a fair trial has been interpreted to me not only the absence of actual bias but even the absence of a probability of unfairness.
To further protect the rights of an accused, our society extends reasonable doubt and presumption of innocence and other burdens in favor of an accused.

Before a confession could be offered in evidence against an accused, he must first have been determined by at the least a preponderance of the evidence to have been knowingly voluntarily and intelligently given.
If it is determined that a jury even considered a coerced confession, it is automatic reversal, can never be a harmless error.

Yet petitioner insist that before a Court can exclude the public including prospective jurors from the hearing involving a coerced confession that the accuse must in open court and in an adversarial proceeding satisfy the awesome standard necessary to justify governmental censorship.
Respondent submit that the standard certainly gives an accused far less than he has a right to expect in our society and under the constitution.

Petitioner bases his argument on the public and potential jurors' right to immediate access to suppression hearing testimony on the fact that the flow of information to the public concerning pretrial suppression hearings is vital to public understanding of the judicial system.
There is no claim here that the press' right to publish is being restrained.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose Mr. Kobroff (Inaudible) it wasn't -- there was a plea here, so it never came to trial.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker

I mean if the jury is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Yes, (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well, I don't know --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I mean these are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Obviuosly they weren't there, obviously.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't think that's necessary.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I think that if you have a record that runs a couple of hundred pages, you can simply buy perhaps picking various --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They wouldn't be as good then, would it?

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: I don't know.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, two is better one.

turn.speaker: bernard_kobroff
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Kobroff
turn.text: It might not be the best of them all.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Two is better than one is that --

Of primary consideration is the public's interest in avoiding anything that would truncate this right.
